elements.title: Years that are subtracted from active academic life (e.g. due to child care). You can enter fractional years, e.g. 0.5.
ORCID identifier (as full link, e.g. https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097)

options.text: I am the applicant & a (co-)author of these research outputs

elements.title: I am aware that all information can be verified. I provide accurate information to the best of my knowledge.

elements.text:
Overall Merit Statement

The overall merit statement summarizes why your research output - across all or some of your publications, data sets, or research software contributions - made an important substantive contribution to the field. This could include, for example:
  • a consistent research programme across multiple papers
  • a new theory that was developed or tested for the first time
  • a series of experiments that rejected or confirmed a long debated effect
Please focus on the overarching merit of your CV. You will be able to provide specific merit statements for each submitted research output.

Do not provide information on societal or scientific impact or information on citation statistics here, but focus on the intrinsic quality of the research output itself - regardless whether it had impact yet or not. Age- and field-normalized citation statistics will be automatically retrieved for each submitted work.

elements.title: Merit Statement (narrative, max. 300 words. Box will expand)

elements.text: 💡 Please enter a DOI to fetch the publication metadata

elements.title: Paper title (automatically added via doi)
Year of publication (automatically added via doi)
Abstract (automatically added via doi)

options.text: This is one of my best papers.
Empirical: Qualitative (e.g., interviews, focus groups, manual content analysis, etc.)
Theoretical contribution (Theory development, formal modeling, etc.)
Non-empirical contribution (Systematic Review, Opinion Piece, Whitepaper, etc.)

elements.title: Does this contribution fit well into the assessment scheme? (If 'No': All indicators are skipped but you can still add a Merit Statement and an Impact Statement. The paper will not be included in the scoring but processed manually)

options.text: No, it should be processed manually (provide explanation)

elements.tip_external: If the fit is not clear already try answer the other indicators first. Most unsuitable papers will have lots of 'not applicable'.

elements.title: Is this paper a multi-study paper?

options.text: No (only a single study is reported)

elements.info:
{:'Yes' | In multi-study papers, sometimes the studies have very different properties (e.g., one is preregistered but the others are not). Therefore, in multi-study papers you need to select one specific study which then is rated.

If you want to include multiple studies from a single multi-study paper, they need to be entered in multiple slots of the rating scheme (as separate publications). In this case, the ratings for all items which are on the paper level (and not on the study level) might be repeated, such as the formal modeling of a theory.}
elements.tip_external: As external rater, you should select the sub-study that (presumably) gains the highest rigor score. Strictly speaking this would require to first score all studies; but for practical reasons we suggest that you skim all studies, select the most promising, and rate that one in the scoring sheet

elements.title: Which of the multiple studies is rated? (Enter a number)

elements.text: [Note: The section on 'CRediT' is automatically disabled as you indicated to be an external rater.]

CRediT roles

Please indicate your individual contributions to the publication. You can get a description of each role by clicking on the name of each role. Where multiple individuals serve in the same role, the degree of contribution should be specified as 'lead', 'equal', or 'supporting'.

  • lead: You were the single leader for this specific activity. If you are the only person in a specific role, choose 'lead'.
  • equal: You contributed equally to this activity, together with one or more other contributors (Choosing this option implies that no other co-author would choose the 'lead' option, and at least one other co-author would choose the 'equal' option).
  • supporting: You had a supporting role, which was below the contribution of a leading or equal role.
  • no role: You did not contribute substantially to that activity.
  • n/a: This role was not relevant for the research.
elements.info:
• lead: You were the single leader for this specific activity. If you are the only person in a specific role, choose 'lead'.
  • equal: You contributed equally to this activity, together with one or more other contributors (Choosing this option implies that no other co-author would choose the 'lead' option, and at least one other co-author would choose the 'equal' option).
  • supporting: You had a supporting role, which was below the contribution of a leading or equal role.
  • no role: You did not contribute substantially to that activity.
  • n/a: This role was not relevant for the research.
elements.background: The CRediT documentation is not very specific about the definition of the lead, equal, and support degrees of contribution. That is also the reason why the Tenzing tool does not implement these levels yet. The rules described here are our interpretation of how these degrees could be used in a reliable way.
elements.tip_external: As an external rater, you are very unlikely to find this information.

elements.title: Was the CRediT information officially published in the paper itself? (Note: add the information in both cases in the table below)

elements.title: Does this paper use any kind of data in a substantive way (new data, reuse of existing data, or simulated data?)
elements.tip_external: Look in the abstract and/or method section.

elements.title: What kind of data do you use? (check all that apply)

options.text: Reuse of own existing data set
Reuse of someone else's existing data set
Aggregating (own or other's) existing data sets

elements.info:
Data set acquisition often is a collaborative enterprise with different contributor roles. { $P_Data_Source_ReuseOwn | Select 'Reuse of own existing data set' only, if you would qualify as a co-author with substantive contributions in a stand-alone data set publication of that data set. Otherwise, select 'Reuse of someone else's existing data set'.}

{ $P_TypeMethod_MetaAnalysis | In case of a meta-analysis, the extraction of effect sizes from the primary literature counts as 'Own new data collection' (but not as 'Reuse of someone else's existing data set'.}
elements.tip_external:
Look in the abstract and/or method section. If no information can be found there, it might also be useful to look at the contributors of the repositories.

Search words: simul*, data, OSF, availab*

options.text: Specific target population, hard to acquire (e.g., babies, inmates, rare disorders)

elements.title: ⤷ Please specify the hard to acquire population
Does the paper investigate a research question for which group differences regarding demographic variables (e.g., culture, age, or gender) are particularly relevant?
Was the sample approximately representative with respect to these potentially relevant demographic variables (e.g., a sample that is not White Educated Industrialized Rich Democratic [WEIRD])?

options.text: Yes, we took care of representativeness

elements.title: ⤷ Please indicate (a) to which target population representativeness was aimed for and (b) which characteristics (e.g., age, gender, education, culture) were explicitly considered.
Are Constraints on Generality explicitly discussed for the participant sample?
Cultural diversity of participant sample / cross-cultural research
elements.info: This question does not necessarily correlate with the nationality of participants. Please make a judgement whether, for example, multiple European subsamples actually qualify as 'Multiple cultural or ethnic backgrounds', or whether different ethnic backgrounds are sampled on purpose within one nation.

elements.title: Does the paper use stimuli in a substantive way?
Representativeness of stimulus sample (within the relevant stimulus population)

options.text: Explicitly considered, stimuli chosen by investigators
Expliclty considered, stimuli randomly sampled from population

elements.title: Are Constraints on Generality explicitly discussed for the stimulus sample?
Type of data (check all that apply)

options.text: Questionnaire (self report), including self-reported behavioral intentions
Content data (e.g., digital traces, text, audiovisual content)
Content or behavioral coding (i.e., converting rich qualitative data into numeric scores)
Meta-analysis: Effect sizes from primary studies

elements.info:
{ $P_Data_Type_MetaAnalysis | In case of meta-analysis, only check 'Meta-analysis: Effect sizes from primary studies'. The data type of the primary studies is irrelevant.}
  • If you process data (for example when you derive numeric scores from a content analysis of interviews), check both the original data type (in the example, 'interviews') and the derived data type (in the example, 'Content or behavioral coding').
  • Some data types are combinations, e.g. if you do an ESM study with mobile sensing, you would choose 'Questionnaire (self report)' and 'Behavioral data' (--> 'Observed behavior (naturalistic situation)' in the next question) and 'longitudinal design' in the question on the study design.
elements.tip_external: Look in the method section, more specifically at parts called procedure, data collection or variables.

elements.title: ⤷ Type of behavioral data (check all that apply)

options.text: Objective performance data (e.g., reaction times, intelligence scores, sales)
Behavioral residues (e.g., sick leave days, number of books)

elements.title: ⤷ Type of physiological data (check all that apply)
Study design
elements.info: When you measure multiple conditions within a single session, this still counts as 'cross-sectional'.

options.text: Low (e.g., reading a vignette; different computerized conditions)
Medium (e.g., staging a social situation in the lab with confederates; tDCS / TMS)
High (e.g., doing a clinical intervention across multiple weeks)

elements.title: Is the raw primary data available in an institutional repository?

options.text: Yes, parts of data [provide doi or URL]
Yes, entire data [provide doi or URL]

elements.info:
If the data is only available on a personal website (including personal university websites) or 'upon (reasonable) request', select not available. When only aggregated data is available, generally select not available (there might be exceptions with high-volume physiological data).

When to choose 'Not applicable'?
  • If legal regulations or binding conditions of the data provider prohibit data publication and not even restricted access is possible.
elements.tip_external:
Practical approach:
  • Is a link to a data set provided?
  • Is the data in a repository that also controls data access?


Search words: open, data, availab*

elements.title: ⤷ Access level
elements.info:
For information about access levels, see here.
  • {:'ZK0' | ZK0 / Sharing level 0 ('open for public use'): Neither access to nor use of the data is restricted in any way. Research data provided in this category are typically licensed through standard licenses (e.g., CC-BY-SA 4.0)}
  • {:'ZK1' | ZK1 / Sharing level 1 ('open for scientific use'): Data re-use is limited to exclusively scientific purposes by means of a general use license. Proof of affiliation with a scientific institution and a brief description of the intended use must be provided.}
  • {:'ZK2' | ZK2 / Sharing level 2 ('restricted scientific use'): Comparable to ZK1, access and re-use is restricted to scientific purposes. In contrast to ZK1, however, individual license agreements are made that may contain other restrictions.}
elements.tip_external:
Practical Approach:

Follow the link and determine the access level. The data must be hosted at a repository and access control decisions must be guarded by a predefined set of rules by the repository (not by the author!).

elements.title: ⤷ Access level ZK2: Justification for restricted access
⤷ FAIR format

options.text: The data set has a globally unique, citable and persistent identifier (e.g., DOI, PURL, ARK)
All variables are comprehensively described in a codebook with a structured format
The data set is stored in a structured, open format (e.g., .csv, .tsv, .tab, .txt, .json; not .sav, .xlsx, .pdf)

elements.info: • Persistent identifier: Data in an OSF project do count, as we consider OSF URLs to be persistent.
elements.tip_external:
For Codebook:
  • Check the availability of a codebook. Normally a separate document should be provided.
  • Exception: Variable labels, descriptions and scales are provided in a structured (e.g. tabular) format at the beginning of the syntax script.
  • Variable name, content and scale must be provided in order to receive the point.

elements.title: Open reproducible scripts

options.text: Parts of scripts are available [provide doi or URL]
The entire analysis pipeline is available, including preprocessing of the primary (raw) data [provide doi or URL]

elements.info:
{'YesParts', 'YesEntire' | Only choose `Yes` if a doi or URL can be provided.}

When only parts of scripts available:
Choose `Yes, parts of scripts` if no justification is given.
Choose `Yes, entire scripts` if a reasonable justification for all missing scripts are provided.

When to choose 'Not applicable':
If no scripts have been used in the publication.

elements.title: ⤷ DOI or URL of the script
elements.info: If multiple sources are available, provide the link to the primary source only. E.g. if both Github and OSF links are available, provide the Github link, as OSF only mirrors the content from Github.

elements.title: ⤷ FAIR format

options.text: The code has an explicitly stated open license (e.g., BSD, CC-BY, (L)GPL, MIT)
Reproducible software environment (e.g. conda environment, renv or groundhog in R)
(Almost) One-click reproducibility with a master script (or equivalent)

elements.info:
• {$P_ReproducibleScripts_FAIR_TimestampedRepository | Timestamped repository: Any repository that records and displays the timestamp when a file has been first uploaded and the last time it has been modified (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, OSF, Zenodo)
    • }
  • {$P_ReproducibleScripts_FAIR_VersionControl |Version control: Any repository that allows to go back in the history of a file with an established version control system, such as git (e.g., GitHub, GitLab. Not OSF or Zenodo.)
    • }
  • {$P_ReproducibleScripts_FAIR_Documentation | Proper documentation of code: The source code has sufficiently detailed comments so that a knowledgable re-user can understand what (and why) something has been done.
    • }
  • {$P_ReproducibleScripts_FAIR_ReproducibleSoftwareEnvironments | Reproducible software environment: The software environment is fully reproducible with an established tool such as conda, renv or groundhog. Just recording the sessionInfo() in R is not sufficient, as it places too much burden on reproduction attempts.
    • }
  • {$P_ReproducibleScripts_FAIR_ReproducibleManuscripts | Reproducible manuscripts: The final manuscript combines computations and text (e.g. Rmarkdown, Quarto, Jupyter notebooks) }
elements.tip_external:
• Search for Open License: This license could be stated in ...
    • A LICENSE file in the top level folder
    • Within the README file
    • In the header of each source code file
    • The OSF project license

elements.title: Correctness of computational results has been independently verified

options.text: Computational reproducibility of MAIN results has been indepedently verified using the original code
Computational reproducibility of ALL numerical results has been independently verified using the original code

elements.info:
• Independent means that someone who is not a co-author verified the computational reproducibility.
  • This only counts if a verification report is published and the doi is provided here (otherwise select 'no').


This has rarely been implemented so far, but some journals already do these independent checks, and universities start to provide pre-submission certification of computational reproducibility.

  • {:'WorkflowReproducible' | Workflow reproducibility / code completeness check: Code runs without errors or critical warnings on another machine by another person (without comparing the numbers). This is also known as process reproducibility.}
  • {:'MainResultsReproducible' | Computational reproducibility of main results has been independently verified using the original code: Someone compared the figures and main results and asserts a sufficient correspondence with the reported main results.}
  • {:'AllResultsReproducible' | Computational reproducibility of all numerical results has been independently verified using the original code: Someone compared all figures and numbers and asserts a sufficient correspondence with the reported results.}
  • {:'AnalysisReplication' | Analysis replication (independent implementation): Somebody independently implemented the analyses, without looking at the original code, and asserts a sufficient correspondence with the reported main results.}

{:'WorkflowReproducible', 'MainResultsReproducible', 'AllResultsReproducible', 'AnalysisReplication' | The bonus point is only given when a public verification report/certificate with a persistent identifier is available.}
elements.background: 'In the context of mathematics, Stodden et al. distinguish between verification and validation; following their definition, a CODECHECK [or reproducibility check] ensures verification of computational results, i.e., checking that code generates the output it claims to create, but not a validation, i.e., checking that the code implements the right algorithm [or statistical model] to solve the specific research problem.' (see Nüst & Eglen, 2021).

elements.title: ⤷ DOI or URL of the verification report
Open materials (beyond the open reproducible scripts entered above)

options.text: Yes, parts of material [provide doi or URL]
Yes, all material necessary for a replication [provide doi or URL]

elements.info:
Open Material refers to all material that is necessary to replicate a study. It typically includes questionnaire items, stimuli, texts for vignettes, or code for software that controls the experimental flow. {:'YesParts', 'YesEntire' | Only choose 'Yes' if the material substantially exceeds the open reproducible scripts. }

  • {:'YesEntire' | Choose 'Yes, entire material' if a reasonable justification for only parts of material is given.}
  • {:'YesParts' | Choose 'Yes, parts of material' if no justification is given. }
  • {:'NotApplicable' | When to choose 'Not applicable': If no material has been used in the publication, or the entire material is contained in the open reproducible scripts. }

The pure existence of an Electronic Supplemental Material does not necessarily count as Open Material, for example if it only contains additional analyses or tables.
elements.tip_external:
• Is a link to open materials provided (don't forget to check Appendix and Supplemental Materials)
  • Expect 'entire material' as default if materials are available (only if the material is obviously not complete and no reasonable explanation is given, assign 'parts of materials')
  • 'Not applicable' is the default if 'reuse of existing data set', 'meta analysis' or 'simulation', but if there is additional material that shows an own contribution then assign 'Yes, entire material'

elements.title: ⤷ DOI or URL of the open materials
⤷ Partial open materials: What is missing? (optional)
Preregistration

options.text: Yes (but not RR) [provide doi or URL]

elements.info:
{:'Yes' | Only choose 'Yes' if the preregistration is time-stamped/registered before the publication of the study (check date).}

Multi Study Paper Case: Only choose 'Yes' if your nominated study has been preregistered.

When to choose 'No'
If the study was not preregistered or if preregistration is not time-stamped/registered

When to choose 'Not applicable':
  • If the study type is 'Simulation' (except from benchmarking experiments), 'mainly theoretical Review' or no data has been used in a substantive way.
    • In rare cases: When the theory arguably is so precise that no preregistration is necessary.
  • There also might be other cases with reasonable justifications for no preregistration.
elements.tip_external:
• It only counts if a link to the preregistration is provided.
  • Search words: preregist*, pre-regist*, regist*, aspredicted, OSF. For clinical trials: Prospero, ClinicalTrials

elements.title: ⤷ DOI or URL of the preregistration
⤷ What has been preregistered? (check all that apply)

options.text: Sample size planning (typically: an a priori power analysis)
Inferential criteria (e.g., defining your alpha level)

elements.info:
• Sample size: Typically, an a priori power analysis was conducted and is reported. Not enough to receive points:
    • 'We will collect as many participants as possible'
    • Only saying which sample size is aimed at without any rationale. Be careful: The AsPredicted template states 'No need to justify decision'. This would not be sufficient in RESQUE.
    • If 'reuse of existing data set': Only reporting how many participants the original study had.


Hypothesis

Hypotheses in the preregistration should be the same as reported in the paper. Deviations must be explained.

Operationalizations

  • If it is ambiguous ('I will use either questionnaire A or B') - without a decision rule - it is 'no'.
  • In a secondary data preregistration ('reuse of existing data set'), the primary outcome should be defined


Analysis Plan

Required to receive points:
  • Dependent and independent variables must be specified (what’s the primary outcome?)
  • Specified decision rule: What’s the alpha-level? When does a result speak in favor of the hypothesis, when against? (especially when multiple testing was conducted)
elements.tip_external:
For Operationalizations:

If you would be able to rebuild the experimental setup based on the preregistered description of the measurement instruments, then assign 'yes'. If it is too vague (e.g. only 'we will use reaction times'), then assign 'no'.

ClinicalTrials.gov often lack the details for most of these aspects (often only the operationalizations are provided, but no sufficiently precise hypotheses, or sample size planning).

elements.title: The paper contains a preregistered replication attempt (either direct/close or conceptual)
elements.info:
As only preregistered replication attempts count, you need to provide the DOI or URL of the preregistration in the previous indicator. If the paper contains a replication which was not preregistered, please select 'No'.

If the paper was preregistered, but does not contain a replication, select 'No'. If you chose 'not applicable' at the previous indicator 'Preregistration', choose 'not applicable' here, too.
elements.tip_external:
If it is a replication of a previously reported effect, it is 'yes', even if the replication is not the main research question of the preregistration.
Search word (in preregistration):replica*

elements.title: Theory-guided research and theory development

options.text: This research was purely descriptive, without clear reference to a theory
In this research, at least one theory was (further) developed and/or evaluated
Not applicable / cannot answer the question

elements.info: If the paper states any theoretically derived hypotheses or the and alike, you should choose the second option here, even if large parts of the study had an exploratory motivation.

elements.text:
Theory usage and development

The following section aims to assess the theoretical rigor of your work, with a formalized version of a theory in a computational model being considered the highest standard.
  • A theory is a set of assumptions about mechanisms that explain empirical phenomena.
  • Phenomena are expressed in robust patterns in the world that have been confirmed in methodologically diverse empirical studies. They are usually not directly observable but implied by observed or measured data patterns. Notably, the assumption of the existence of the phenomenon may be false (e.g., due to errors in the measurement).
  • Mechanisms that explain phenomena are typically described using concepts (e.g., person, situation, attitude, motive, etc.) and relations among these concepts. We call these the 'elements of a theory'. Eventually, the elements specified within the theory should be able to reproduce the data pattern that resembles the data pattern reflective of the assumed phenomenon.
Whether or not the pattern exists in reality is relevant regarding the theory’s ultimate utility, but it is irrelevant in terms of how precisely, transparently and comprehensively the theory itself is presented. A theory may be well-specified and still wrong.

A model is a formalization of a (part of a) theory in accordance with some set of standard notation rules (e.g., algebra). A model always consists of mathematical or formal-logic elements such as variables, scalars and constants, as well as exact specifications of the ways in which these are related to one another. The formulation of a model should always enable to run concrete simulations, thereby increasing the precision, objectivity, and falsifiability of a theory. Please note that there is a difference between 1) a computational model of your theory, which aims to explain your data by formalizing a data-generating process, and 2) a statistical model of your data, which aims to describe patterns within the data but without offering an explanation of how that data was generated. In the following, the term “model” is used in the former way.
elements.info:
The following section aims to assess the theoretical rigor of your work, with a formalized version of a theory in a computational model being considered the highest standard.

It is important to distinguish between 1) a computational model of your theory, which aims to explain your data by formalizing a data-generating process, and 2) a statistical model of your data, which aims to describe patterns in your data.

elements.title: Hygiene standards for papers developing and/or evaluating at least one theory. The paper …

options.text: contains an explicit narrative account of the phenomena that are to be explained, and of one or more hypothetical mechanisms accounting for them.
contains explicit narrative definitions of each element (e.g., concepts, relationships between concepts) in the theory.
specifies the conditions that must be met for the theory to apply to the phenomena.

contains a formalized account of the theory (i.e., a model). That is, all properties and connections among the elements of the theory are expressed in a formalized way (see explanations for examples), and the model attempts to reproduce the to-be-explained phenomenon.

elements.info:
The following criteria also apply when reusing or testing a previously developed model. In this case, they refer to the previous work that is referenced in the paper and any deviations, additions and adaptations reported in the current work.

  • Phenomena are robust patterns in the world that have been confirmed in methodologically diverse empirical studies. While they are not always directly observable, they are implied by observation or measurement.
  • 'conditions that must be met': For example, for which population, under which situational characteristics.
  • A formalized account of the theory can be achieved in various ways, typically by specifying the theory with (1) formal-logic (e.g., if-then propositions, rules of logic), (2) mathematical equations, or (3) in an agent-based (i.e., specification of individual entities and their interactions to simulate their effect on the system), or (4) algorithmic model. Oftentimes, a model will mix multiple approaches (e.g., an agent-based model can include equations and / or computer code).

elements.title: In what language or system is the model formulated?
elements.info: More than one possible. Please tick all that apply.

elements.title: The paper …

options.text: lists all elements of the model alongside their definitions in a clearly arranged form (e.g., in a table).
explicates the basic mathematical properties of all elements of the model (e.g., scalar vs. matrix; dimensionality; units carrying the information).
explicates the possible values for all elements of the model (i.e., upper and lower bounds, scale level).
contains one or more simulation(s) to explore the ability of the model to reproduce the to-be-explained phenomenon.
contains one or more simulation(s) to explore additional implications of the theory.

elements.info:
Please apply these questions to the theory in your paper - regardless whether you (further) developed the theory or used someone else’s theory.

  • Under elements of a model we subsume fixed and free parameters, scaling constants, measurable variables, and outcomes.
  • Basic mathematical properties: For example, if a formalization only contains Y = a*B + c, even if all elements have a narrative definition, the mathematical properties might be unclear: For instance, is B a constant, a vector, or a two-dimensional matrix?
  • The simulations do not necessarily involve empirical data.

elements.title: Did you test (a part of) this theory with empirical data?
elements.info: Testing the empirical consistency of a theory usually involves the comparison of a concrete prediction from the theory against empirical data. This can involve simulations but does necessarily require them.

elements.text:
Theory Evaluation

Theories may be evaluated in terms of how well they predict or reproduce data patterns that are indicative of the to-be-explained phenomenon. To do so, the elements of the theory that are to be included in the evaluation need to be “operationalized”. Evaluating a theory does not require its formalization but doing so will usually result in a more precise and objective test. Evaluating only parts of a theory is possible and legitimate.

An optimal theory evaluation contains an explicit account of which of the theory’s elements are (not) evaluated, how each of these elements are represented in the design of the respective empirical study, and how the assumed phenomenon is represented in the observable data. An optimal theory evaluation also contains precise predictions, criteria for how they may be falsified, an assessment of how well the theory’s predictions fit the observable data, and a discussion of what the findings mean for the theory.
elements.info:
The following section aims to assess the theoretical rigor of your work, with a formalized version of a theory in a computational model being considered the highest standard.

It is important to distinguish between 1) a computational model of your theory, which aims to explain your data by formalizing a data-generating process, and 2) a statistical model of your data, which aims to describe patterns in your data.

elements.title: The paper describes all additional assumptions that were necessary to make the theory testable, by stating which, why, and how elements of the theory were ...
elements.info: This also includes ad-hoc assumptions.

elements.title: The paper makes clear how the tested predictions logically and stringently follow from the theory by ...

options.text: explicitly deriving the tested predictions from a formalized version of the theory.

elements.info:
More than one possible. Please tick all that apply. To gain all points, a formalized derivation of predictions should be accompanied by a narrative walkthrough.
  • A narrative derivation explains the reasoning in a comprehensible manner using natural language terms, such that a competent person can follow the argumentation
  • A formalized derivation is objective, in the sense that any competent person would come to the same prediction.

options.text: evaluates the relative and/or absolute fit of the theory to the empirical data with appropriate procedures (e.g., qualitative reproduction of empirical patterns, cross-validation, AIC, Bayes Factors).
contains an explicit discussion as to what the results mean for the theory that was tested (e.g., refutation, limitation of scope, adding or subtracting theory elements).

elements.text:
Sample size and power considerations

The boxes will expand when you enter text; you can simply copy and paste the relevant sections from the paper.

elements.title: Please report all considerations regarding statistical power (assumed effect size, power, N, ...).
Sample size (if applicable, differentiate by levels / items / ...)

elements.text:
Merit Statement

A merit statement summarizes why this research output made an important substantive contribution to the field. Such statements could reflect upon, for example:
  • an interdisciplinary setting
  • a new theory that was developed or tested for the first time
  • a methodological set-up that was specifically innovative
  • an unusually great effort was needed to collect the sample
  • generalizability was particularly high

Do not provide information on societal or scientific impact or information on citation statistics here, but focus on the intrinsic quality of the research output itself - regardless whether it had impact yet or not.

elements.title: Provide your Merit Statement here (narrative, max. 150 words. Box will expand):

elements.text:
Scientific Impact Statement

Age- and field-normalized citation statistics will be automatically retrieved for each submitted work. Here you can describe the scientific impact that this work made beyond these bibliometric indicators (e.g., explain how your methodological contribution was recommended as the go-to-approach in a consensus paper on best practice in the field).

elements.title: Provide your Scientific Impact Statement here (narrative, max. 150 words. Box will expand):
Short title of the research software
Short description of the research software
License

options.text: Other open source (listed in OSI; please specify)

elements.info:
Is the software open source? Open-source software makes broader impact more likely and is a prerequisite for full transparency and reproducibility (Peikert, Van Lissa, & Brandmaier, 2021). In addition, many aspects of rigor are impossible to evaluate for closed-source software — for example, whether it is well-tested or bugs have been fixed.

Approved open licenses are listed at opensource.org/licenses. The Creative Commons licenses are not listed there, because they were not designed to operate on software code. Because of their wide application, however, we accept CC0, CC-BY and CC-BY-SA as open licenses as well.
Please specify your own contribution to the project.

elements.title: Is the codebase actively maintained?
elements.info:
Is the codebase actively maintained?

i.e., reported bugs are quickly fixed (in less than 2 weeks) and it is ensured that it stays functional in an evolving environment. This does not require new features.

Please answer this question for the software, independent of your own contribution.

elements.title: Is a community actively mainteined?

options.text: Yes, high volume (some interaction per week)
Yes, medium volume (some interactions per month)
Yes, low volume (some interaction per year)

elements.info:
Is a community actively maintained?

(e.g., users can ask questions and report bugs, and maintainers typically react in less than 2 weeks; e.g., workshops are given)

Please answer this question for the software, independent of your own contribution.

elements.title: Do tests for main functionality exist?
elements.info:
Do tests for main functionality exist?

e.g., unit testing, functional testing, integration testing. Having trivial unit tests for few functions does not count)

options.text: The code for the tests is open source
Different test classes are employed (unit / functional / integration)
Test results are public and reproducible by users (please provide URL)
All user-facing functionality is meaningfully tested

elements.title: ⤷ URL to the test code results
Documentation

options.text: It is documented how to ask questions about usage and possible bugs
User facing functionality is documented (e.g., ?help in R)
Longform documentations exist (e.g., vignettes, tutorials, annotated workflow examples)
Developer documentation exists (e.g., how to extend the software, extensive inline code commentaries)

elements.info: Just like for tests, there are different types of documentation. For example, tutorials showcase software usage with examples, and there is application programming interface (API) documentation for individual functions and classes to enable reusing functions in other software packages. We propose to identify relevant categories of documentation for research software, e.g., installation instructions, tutorials, API, and community guidelines (also see joss.readthedocs.io).

options.text: A simple, short tutorial for getting started
A long tutorial or multiple tutorials which cover >= 80% of all use cases in detail
Some commentary on the internal structure and design
Gives an example ('this is how you implement a new interface')

elements.title: Merit / impact statement (narrative, max. 150 words)
elements.info: In what way does the research software product make a significant contribution to the scientific field? Merits and aspects of the contribution that are not covered by the above indicators should also be mentioned here. Indicate at least one (and up to three) research projects that directly benefited from your software contribution. You may report citation/download statistics/Github stars, but be aware that these are hard to compare between different software types and are easily gameable.
